name: Walmart
title: What could end up being Walmart's biggest 2026 tailwind - Yahoo Finance
description:
Let's talk about the holiday season and just kind of wrap 2025 and set up 2026 for us broadly.
There were a number of estimates that suggested that retail sales would be in the low single digits.
It ended up being in the mid-single digits around the 4% um, gain range, and even higher than that for e-commerce.
The big question is what happens in 2026, um, because there is just so much uncertainty with the economy, with interest rates, um, and of course with consumer confidence continuing to go down.
They gained share through the pandemic and continue to hold on to that share.
text:
Let's talk about the holiday season and just kind of wrap 2025 and set up 2026 for us broadly.

Well, 2025 did pretty well. There was a relatively strong momentum in spite of consumer confidence levels. Even through the holiday season, we saw stronger than expected numbers. There were a number of estimates that suggested that retail sales would be in the low single digits. Um, some players even thought it would be negative. It ended up being in the mid-single digits around the 4% um, gain range, and even higher than that for e-commerce. Um, so the momentum of retail has been strong in 2025. The big question is what happens in 2026, um, because there is just so much uncertainty with the economy, with interest rates, um, and of course with consumer confidence continuing to go down.

And let's talk about Walmart and some of the other uh big retailers that are getting new CEOs, Target as well, and I don't know if these are on your coverage list, but I'm just going to list them because they're in the news as well. Camping World, Craft Heinz, Kohl's, Lulu Lemon, 7-Eleven, uh and it seems like changes in the air. So talk to us more specifically about Walmart and Target, please.

Well, Target has struggled a lot in the last few years and I am not entirely confident that um new leadership is going to write that ship. There are a number of operational and executional issues that they need to address. Walmart on the other hand has been on a roll. They have been doing incredibly well for several years. They gained share through the pandemic and continue to hold on to that share. They've invested heavily um both in their physical store experience, which is of course still the majority of their sales and they also have managed to continue to take share even in the dotcom and e-commerce sector. So those are things that are absolutely in Walmart's favor. Um and it's uh the new CEO of Walmart um likely is uh has a has a hard task ahead of them because they because the company has um has been doing so well to continue to grow on top of that is not going to be particularly easy. But that said, um if there is an economic downturn and if consumers do cut back on spending in 2026, these mass merchants like Walmart and Costco are likely to be beneficiaries.

name: Capgemini
title: In an AI world, BPM industry embraces AI to rethink the BPO future - Business Standard
description:
The deal has forced a rethink of the future of business process management (BPM) — not as a low-margin, labour-heavy adjunct to information-technology (IT) services but as a business being repositioned for an AI-led operating model.
You can redesign the process end-to-end and embed AI, GenAI (generative AI), and agentic AI.
BPO providers need to invest heavily in agentic AI and those are the ones that will survive,” said Saurabh Gupta, president, research and advisory, HfS Research.
Many BPM companies have moved on to providing process optimisation and are delivering end-to-end solutions on process transformation rather than process management services.
Companies such as Genpact have launched “account payables as an agent”, decoupling from traditional services and focusing more on expertise, innovation, and outcome-driven solutions.
text:
Yet, even as many agreed with this prediction, the sector delivered one of its biggest surprises in years: Capgemini’s $3.3 billion acquisition of WNS. The deal has forced a rethink of the future of business process management (BPM) — not as a low-margin, labour-heavy adjunct to information-technology (IT) services but as a business being repositioned for an AI-led operating model.

Explaining the rationale behind the acquisition, Capgemini Chief Executive Officer (CEO) Aiman Ezzat said BPM remained one of the fastest-growing segments.

“It is interesting to see that a business many assumed would eventually die is the one growing the fastest,” Ezzat said in an interaction with Business Standard. “For us the big opportunity lies in the complete transformation of end-to-end processes. For instance, take the claims process in insurance. You can redesign the process end-to-end and embed AI, GenAI (generative AI), and agentic AI. Such a transformation is complex and requires defining processes at a granular level. WNS gives us that capability,” said Ezzat.

The year 2026 is a year when the industry crosses the threshold from traditional BPM to intelligent operations powered by AI and driven by humans in the loop.

For decades, this industry — just like IT companies — depended on headcount–based delivery, fixed pricing models, and labour-intensive operations. But the impact of AI and GenAI is changing that play.

“This industry will look different in the next two years. BPO providers need to invest heavily in agentic AI and those are the ones that will survive,” said Saurabh Gupta, president, research and advisory, HfS Research.

“They have to reinvent themselves with technology providers coming into the BPO space as well. CommoditiSed BPOs will be hit the hardest and the ones that provide contextual services tailored to the needs of customers will survive.”

The BPM industry, worth $54.6 billion in 2024-25, according to the Nasscom data, continues to count the United States as its largest market, which is contributing about half its top line, with Europe adding another 30 per cent.

Banking financial services and insurance (BFSI) provides about 30 per cent of the revenue while hospitality and telecom contribute about 20 per cent each.

While the industry last year grew 4.7 per cent, its trajectory will depend solely on how fast it is able to adapt to the new technology. Many BPM companies have moved on to providing process optimisation and are delivering end-to-end solutions on process transformation rather than process management services. They are also moving beyond traditional pricing models to outcome-based pricing, often adopting a hybrid model depending on the specifics of each engagement.

“This transition is reshaping work. As workflows become more autonomous and data-rich, people will move into higher-order roles that demand judgement, orchestration, and strategic decision making, unlocking a level of performance previously out of reach. At industry level, this will accelerate consolidation because only organisations with true scale, deep domain depth, and strong platforms will be capable of leading the AI-enabled Digital BPS market,” said Keshav Murugesh, group CEO, WNS.

This shift is visible in how BPM firms are redesigning their offers. Companies such as Genpact have launched “account payables as an agent”, decoupling from traditional services and focusing more on expertise, innovation, and outcome-driven solutions. Such moves may cannibalise their existing revenue but analysts say they need to adopt it to be an agentic company rather than a pure-play BPO.

“These agentic solutions are taking hold with new clients who are net new to Genpact or are net new to that particular agentic solution,” Genpact CEO Balkrishnan Kalra said in a call with analysts in November.

This means traditional BPOs, which will continue to provide legacy services in finance and accounting, payroll management, contact centre, and supply-chain management, need to reinvent or get acquired because clients would not be ready to pay for the huge workforce.

Gaurav Vasu, founder of UnearthInsights, said: “Pure-play BPOs will find it hard to survive. We will see technology plus people plus industry domains come in and they will provide the business capability.”

name: Michelin
title: DP World Lions reflect on a powerful 2025 and look ahead to an exciting 2026 - The Citizen
description:
As 2025 draws to an end, the DP World Lions are taking a moment to look back on a year filled with achievement, community spirit, and memorable moments both on and off the field.
Reflecting on the past 12 months, DP World Lions CEO Jono Leaf-Wright said he could not be more proud of what the team and its wider family have accomplished.
We impacted, influenced, and inspired greatness and growth at every level.” Leaf-Wright emphasised that the success of the year would not have been possible without those who make up the Lions community.
“SA20 starts on January 1, 2026, with the Joburg Super Kings kicking off the new year in style,” he said.
After that, our DP World Lions men and women will be challenging for titles in the 4 Day Series, One-Day Cup, and T20.” Leaf-Wright encouraged supporters to be part of the celebrations throughout the season.
text:
As 2025 draws to an end, the DP World Lions are taking a moment to look back on a year filled with achievement, community spirit, and memorable moments both on and off the field.

Reflecting on the past 12 months, DP World Lions CEO Jono Leaf-Wright said he could not be more proud of what the team and its wider family have accomplished. “We hit 2025 hard,” he said.

“We struck the sweet spot in both our on-field and off-field efforts, and for that I am incredibly proud. We celebrated good players and grew great people. We impacted, influenced, and inspired greatness and growth at every level.”

Leaf-Wright emphasised that the success of the year would not have been possible without those who make up the Lions community. “None of this would’ve been possible without the support of our cricketing community far and wide,” he said. “I thank you for striding forth with a positive attitude, tremendous energy, and a deep-rooted pride in the Lions Cricket family and everyone who works tirelessly to grow the game we love.”

Read more: New head coach appointed to lead DP World Women’s Lions into next season

He highlighted the busy and exciting months to come. “SA20 starts on January 1, 2026, with the Joburg Super Kings kicking off the new year in style,” he said.

“Then we end January with the special Pink Day on the 31st, when our Protea men take on the West Indies in a T20 International. After that, our DP World Lions men and women will be challenging for titles in the 4 Day Series, One-Day Cup, and T20.”

Leaf-Wright encouraged supporters to be part of the celebrations throughout the season. “Tickets are on sale for all matches, and we would love everyone to join us, not only for the games I’ve mentioned, but for every fixture in 2026,” he said.

Also read: Wanderers Junior Cricket calls young players to the crease

As the festive season approaches, he shared his warm wishes with the entire community. “I wish you a wonderful break with your loved ones. Thank you for your commitment and for your unwavering love of our Pride throughout 2025.”

He also expressed deep appreciation for the organisation’s partners. “A huge thank you to our extraordinary stakeholders and partners. We love hunting with you and truly value your continued support.”

Looking back on a fast-paced and fulfilling year, he added one final note of gratitude. “We came at 2025 hard and fast, with you backing us all the way. Thank you.”

name: Eli Lilly
title: Key facts: Eli Lilly Q3 revenues soar 53.9% to $17.6B; weight-loss drug launch planned
description:
Less than 1 min read Eli Lilly's Q3 revenues hit $17.6 billion, up 53.9% year-on-year, exceeding forecasts by 9.7%.
The stock rose 32.7% since the report, now trading at $1,077.1 Eli Lilly plans to launch an oral weight-loss drug, orforglipron, pending regulatory approval.
The pill will be priced at $149 for starters and $399 for repeat buyers.2
text:

name: Nvidia
title: AI chipmakers that could steal some of Nvidia's spotlight in 2026 - Yahoo Finance
description:
But uh we've seen in the Mag 5, for instance, we used to kind of talk about them or the Mag 7 uh as a whole.
It's really only Alphabet and Nvidia, maybe Tesla as a come behind story that have really surged this year.
But obviously I think, you know, you're going to continue to see folks like Nvidia and AMD do well.
So, I think we're going to see a lot of different players uh from different areas uh all start to come together.
Uh there's a little company called SiTime that does uh timing chips and all these networks have to be completely aligned from a timing perspective.
text:
And another thing people have been uh some of the critics have been pouuncing on is all the spending, the capital expenditures, so-called CAPEX. Uh we saw that it's been exploding over the last few years. It's set to continue next year. But uh we've seen in the Mag 5, for instance, we used to kind of talk about them or the Mag 7 uh as a whole. It's really only Alphabet and Nvidia, maybe Tesla as a come behind story that have really surged this year. So is it a game of have and have nots or how do you see this playing out?

No, it's a great question. I mean, look, I think Nvidia obviously continues to do well, but I also am certain that Nvidia is going to heck get a heck of a lot more competition in 2026. AMD is, you know, an obvious one, but there's a lot of other little players. I mean, you know, Nvidia's uh deal with Grock recently to bring more of their technology in is a reflection of the fact that we're seeing more specialized types of models being developed. We're we're going from the days of big general purpose LLMs that you can use for everything to much more specialized areas. And each of those are going to require different types of hardware and I think in turn that's going to create additional opportunities, but it's going to create more diversity, which is going to be a little harder to figure out. But obviously I think, you know, you're going to continue to see folks like Nvidia and AMD do well. I do, as I said, I think you're going to start to see uh some of the smaller the cloud guys who are doing custom chips often through Broadcom will also start to benefit. We've seen already, you know, Google's been doing more with TPUs, uh Amazon has their Graviton chips. Um, we've got a a bunch of other companies. Microsoft is doing custom chips. A lot of these are arm-based. So arm is another company, you know, we haven't been talking about them a lot lately, but arm's helping drive some of this innovation. Intel, as you've talked about, you know, is doing well. They continue to plug away. Obviously, they had their challenges last year, but things are looking better in 2026. So, I think we're going to see a lot of different players uh from different areas uh all start to come together. And we'll see some smaller companies. Uh there's a little company called SiTime that does uh timing chips and all these networks have to be completely aligned from a timing perspective. They're doing some interesting stuff. So, I think there's a lot of different opportunities in different areas. Um but we're going to have a lot of the bears on the side just again, waiting to pounce on these oper these concerns that get raised, I think around a gentic AI.

And we'll have to see if those are dips worth buying or not. And Bob, what I'm realizing is we got to do another podcast real soon. So thank you for showing up.

Yeah, man, I'd love to.

It was great seeing you here.

Thanks, Jared.

name: OpenAI
title: Can OpenAI-led Conversational Commerce Drive TGT's Next Growth Wave?
description:
OpenAI is emerging as a key strength in Target Corporation’s TGT next phase of digital transformation, as the retailer leans heavily on conversational commerce to reaccelerate growth.
TGT’s partnership with OpenAI represents a timely leap forward in how consumers discover and purchase products online.
On-shelf availability for key items improved more than 150 basis points year over year across TGT’s top 5,000 items.
While discretionary softness remains a headwind, OpenAI-led conversational commerce could provide TGT with a new demand engine.
If early traction in marketplace GMV and Roundel ad growth continues, this shift toward AI-powered shopping may meaningfully advance TGT’s digital-led trajectory heading into 2026.
text:
OpenAI is emerging as a key strength in Target Corporation’s TGT next phase of digital transformation, as the retailer leans heavily on conversational commerce to reaccelerate growth. In third-quarter fiscal 2025, TGT reported 2.4% digital comps growth and more than 35% expansion in same-day services, reinforcing that guests increasingly expect intuitive, fast and digitally assisted shopping experiences. TGT’s partnership with OpenAI represents a timely leap forward in how consumers discover and purchase products online.

At the core of this initiative is the ability for guests to shop directly through natural-language conversations. By describing what they need — whether a gift idea, a household item or products tied to a specific budget — shoppers receive curated recommendations without navigating menus or search bars. This AI-driven approach aims to replicate the feel of a personalized in-store experience, while streamlining the digital journey from discovery to checkout.

The partnership will also integrate tightly with TGT’s fulfillment ecosystem. Guests will be able to complete multi-item purchases, select Drive Up or pickup options and even shop for fresh foods — all within an OpenAI-powered chat interface. With two-day delivery available to 99% of U.S. households and next-day capabilities now covering more than half the country, TGT is uniquely positioned to operationalize this conversational demand at scale.

Supporting these innovations is a robust AI backbone already reshaping internal operations. Tools like Target Trend Brain and synthetic audiences help identify trends early and test consumer response before launch. On-shelf availability for key items improved more than 150 basis points year over year across TGT’s top 5,000 items.

While discretionary softness remains a headwind, OpenAI-led conversational commerce could provide TGT with a new demand engine. If early traction in marketplace GMV and Roundel ad growth continues, this shift toward AI-powered shopping may meaningfully advance TGT’s digital-led trajectory heading into 2026.

WMT & BBY Advance AI Efforts While TGT Upgrades Its Platform

name: Walmart
title: Walmart's $152M deal signals Arizona's logistics real estate boom - FreightWaves
description:
As of Monday, SONAR’s Outbound Tender Rejection Index (OTRI) for the Phoenix market stood at 7.42%, rising week over week and signaling potential tightening in local trucking capacity.
Last-mile and logistics firms follow region’s growth Arizona’s population growth and industrial build-out are also drawing logistics service providers focused on speed and specialization.
The company said Arizona’s growth and proximity to Southern California make it an ideal launchpad for regional expansion, according to a news release.
Specialized logistics firms are also scaling up alongside Phoenix’s industrial real estate boom.
Rail investment strengthens Arizona’s freight backbone Infrastructure investment is reinforcing Arizona’s appeal as a logistics destination.
text:
“Its prime location makes Luke Field a logistics powerhouse. We appreciate the trust being placed in this building by our first official tenant, and look forward to ongoing success as we continue to field strong prospect interest in the project’s remaining available buildings,” Lincoln Property Co. executive vice president John Orsak said in a news release.

As of Monday, SONAR’s Outbound Tender Rejection Index (OTRI) for the Phoenix market stood at 7.42%, rising week over week and signaling potential tightening in local trucking capacity. The increase suggests carriers are becoming more selective as prolonged low rates continue to push marginal operators out of the market.

While tender rejections are climbing, outbound volumes in Phoenix have remained relatively flat or declined compared with the same period in 2024 and 2023. That divergence points to a shifting balance of power, with carriers gaining leverage despite muted demand — an early indication that spot rates could begin moving higher and the shipper-friendly environment may be fading.

Industrial development accelerates around Phoenix

Walmart’s purchase comes amid a wave of new industrial construction across the Phoenix area, particularly in submarkets tied to advanced manufacturing and semiconductor investment.

In north Phoenix’s Deer Valley area, ViaWest Group and Barings have broken ground on ReDiscover Logistics Park, an 808,448-square-foot Class A industrial development targeting suppliers, manufacturers and distributors serving Arizona’s expanding chip ecosystem, In Business Magazine reported.

The site sits around 15 minutes from Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co.’s multibillion-dollar fabrication campus, positioning it as a logistics hub for high-value, time-sensitive freight.

Last-mile and logistics firms follow region’s growth

Arizona’s population growth and industrial build-out are also drawing logistics service providers focused on speed and specialization.

Jet Delivery, a 75-year-old same-day and time-critical logistics provider, recently launched Phoenix operations, citing demand from healthcare, manufacturing, aerospace, tech and e-commerce customers for reliable last-mile coverage in the rapidly expanding metro area.

At the same time, Phoenix-based startup Speedora has entered the market with an asset-owned, white-glove delivery model for big and bulky freight, targeting retailers frustrated with damage claims and broker-heavy networks.

The company said Arizona’s growth and proximity to Southern California make it an ideal launchpad for regional expansion, according to a news release.

Specialized logistics firms are also scaling up alongside Phoenix’s industrial real estate boom. RK Logistics Group recently opened an 80,000-square-foot, temperature-controlled warehouse in Tempe, doubling its Phoenix-area footprint to nearly 158,000 square feet to support semiconductor, electric vehicle and renewable energy customers.

Company executives pointed to proximity to Sky Harbor International Airport, interstate highways and rail intermodal facilities as key advantages, reinforcing metro Phoenix’s growing role as a hub for high-value, time-sensitive freight.

Rail investment strengthens Arizona’s freight backbone

Infrastructure investment is reinforcing Arizona’s appeal as a logistics destination. Union Pacific recently completed a major expansion of its Casa Grande Yard west of Tucson, doubling capacity and adding new tracks, industrial leads and signal upgrades along the railroad’s Sunset Route.

The yard serves local industries and supports manifest freight moving across the Southwest.

Rail capacity upgrades are critical to handling growing inbound materials and outbound finished goods tied to manufacturing growth across the state, particularly as shippers seek alternatives to congested coastal gateways.

name: OpenAI
title: OpenAI seeks new safety chief as Altman flags growing risks - The Register
description:
Over the weekend, OpenAI boss Sam Altman went public with a search for a new Head of Preparedness, saying rapidly improving AI models are creating new risks that need closer oversight.
Altman flagged an opening for the company's Head of Preparedness on Saturday in a post on X.
"We have a strong foundation of measuring growing capabilities," Altman said, "but we are entering a world where we need more nuanced understanding and measurement of how those capabilities could be abused."
This, mind you, came in the wake of a number of high-profile safety leadership exits at the company and a partial reset of OpenAI's safety team structure.
Weng left OpenAI in November 2024, while Candela left his role as head of preparedness in April for a three-month coding internship at OpenAI.
text:
How’d you like to earn more than half a million dollars working for one of the world’s fastest-growing tech companies? The catch: the job is stressful, and the last few people tasked with it didn’t stick around. Over the weekend, OpenAI boss Sam Altman went public with a search for a new Head of Preparedness, saying rapidly improving AI models are creating new risks that need closer oversight.

Altman flagged an opening for the company's Head of Preparedness on Saturday in a post on X. Describing the role, which carries a $555,000 base salary plus equity, as one focused on securing OpenAI's systems and understanding how they could be abused, Altman also noted that AI models are beginning to present "some real challenges" as they rapidly improve and gain new capabilities.

"The potential impact of models on mental health was something we saw a preview of in 2025," Altman said, without elaborating on specific cases or products.

AI has been flagged as an increasingly common trigger of psychological troubles in both juveniles and adults, with chatbots reportedly linked to multiple deaths in the past year. OpenAI, one of the most popular chatbot makers in the market, rolled back a GPT-4o update in April 2025 after acknowledging it had become overly sycophantic and could reinforce harmful or destabilizing user behavior.

Despite that, OpenAI released ChatGPT-5.1 last month, which included a number of emotional dependence-nurturing features, like the inclusion of emotionally-suggestive language, "warmer, more intelligent" responses, and the like. Sure, it might be less sycophantic, but it'll speak to you with more intimacy than ever before, making it feel more like a human companion instead of the impersonal, logical ship computer from Star Trek that spits facts with little regard for feeling.

It's no wonder the company needs someone to steer the ship with regard to model safety.

"We have a strong foundation of measuring growing capabilities," Altman said, "but we are entering a world where we need more nuanced understanding and measurement of how those capabilities could be abused."

According to the job posting, the Head of Preparedness will be responsible for leading technical strategy and execution of OpenAI's preparedness framework [PDF], which the company describes as its approach "to tracking and preparing for frontier capabilities that create new risks of severe harm."

It's not a new role, mind you, but it's one that's seen more turnover than the Defense Against Dark Arts faculty position at Hogwarts.

Aleksander Madry, director of MIT's Center for Deployable Machine Learning and faculty leader at the Institute's AI Policy Forum, occupied the Preparedness role until July 2024, when OpenAI reassigned him to a reasoning-focused research role.

This, mind you, came in the wake of a number of high-profile safety leadership exits at the company and a partial reset of OpenAI's safety team structure.

OpenAI's Atlas shrugs off inevitability of prompt injection, releases AI browser anyway

OpenAI turns the screws on chatbots to get them to confess mischief

Some like it bot! ChatGPT promises AI-rotica is coming for verified adults

OpenAI reorg at risk as Attorneys General push AI safety

In Madry's place, OpenAI appointed Joaquin Quinonero Candela and Lilian Weng to lead the preparedness team. Both occupied other roles at OpenAI prior to heading up preparedness, but neither lasted long in the position. Weng left OpenAI in November 2024, while Candela left his role as head of preparedness in April for a three-month coding internship at OpenAI. While still an OpenAI employee, he's out of the technical space entirely and is now serving as head of recruiting.

"This will be a stressful job and you'll jump into the deep end pretty much immediately," Altman said of the open position.

Understandably so - OpenAI and model safety have long had a contentious relationship, as numerous ex-employees have attested. One executive who left the company in October called the Altman outfit out for not being as focused on safety and the long-term effects of its AGI push as it should be, suggesting that the company was pushing ahead in its goal to dominate the industry at the expense of the rest of society.

Will $555,000 be enough to keep a new Preparedness chief in the role? Skepticism may be warranted.

OpenAI didn't respond to questions for this story. ®

name: Nvidia
title: Following Nvidia? Mark Your Calendars for March 16. - Yahoo Finance
description:
Key Points Nvidia GTC is scheduled for March 16-19.
Nvidia GTC is set for March The Nvidia GTC AI conference will take place in San Jose, Calif., from March 16 to 19, 2026.
Prediction Market powered by Nvidia publishes many of its GTC conference sessions online.
See the 10 stocks » *Stock Advisor returns as of December 29, 2025 Lyle Daly has positions in Nvidia.
Mark Your Calendars for March 16. was originally published by The Motley Fool
text:
Key Points

Nvidia GTC is scheduled for March 16-19.

The last GTC included the announcement of Blackwell Ultra GPUs and the shift to agentic AI.

10 stocks we like better than Nvidia ›

Nvidia (NASDAQ: NVDA) has been at the forefront of the artificial intelligence (AI) boom, which is largely why it now tops the list of the world's largest public companies.

The chipmaker hosts several events each year that are worth checking out if you're following Nvidia or simply want to stay up-to-date on AI technology. One of its biggest events is just a few months away, and it's worth adding to your calendar.

Nvidia GTC is set for March

The Nvidia GTC AI conference will take place in San Jose, Calif., from March 16 to 19, 2026. It will feature developers, researchers, and business leaders, including Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang delivering his keynote speech.

This conference is often when Nvidia announces new products and its roadmap. At GTC 2025, it announced its next-generation GPU, the Blackwell Ultra, and its successor, the Rubin platform. The 2025 conference is also where Huang spoke about a shift in focus from generative AI to agentic AI, which can autonomously reason, plan, and execute tasks.

Prediction Market powered by

Nvidia publishes many of its GTC conference sessions online. It's a great opportunity to learn about the future of AI and discover what Nvidia has in store. While keeping up with everything would be time-consuming, investors should consider at least reviewing the highlights. After all, AI has become extremely important to the tech sector and the stock market as a whole.

Should you buy stock in Nvidia right now?

Before you buy stock in Nvidia, consider this:

name: Ralph Lauren
title: Lululemon's Founder Pitches Three for Top Executive Position | Modaes Global
authors: Modaes, Pilar Riaño, Pablo Bueno, CEO of LVMH, CEO of Kering, CEO of Inditex, CEO of Richemont, CEO of GAP, CEO of Nike
description:
The founder of Lululemon, Chip Wilson, is making a move to secure the most important position in the sports equipment company: that of CEO.
According to The Wall Street Journal, the businessman has proposed three candidates for the position.
The businessman is Lululemon’s second largest shareholder, with a stake of close to 9%.
The founder believes that shareholders will not trust any CEO proposed by the current board, so he has initiated the dispute for control of the board.
The founder held the chairmanship until 2013, when a scandal over a television interview caused him to resign.
text:
The founder of Lululemon, Chip Wilson, is making a move to secure the most important position in the sports equipment company: that of CEO. According to The Wall Street Journal, the businessman has proposed three candidates for the position.

Wilson has proposed Marc Maurer, former CEO of On; Laura Gentile, former marketing director of the U.S. television channel group Espn, and Eric Hirshberg, former CEO of Activision. The businessman is Lululemon’s second largest shareholder, with a stake of close to 9%.

Lululemon announced in December the departure of its CEO, Calvin McDonald, after seven years at the company, under pressure to turn the business around. Wilson, in fact, was one of the voices that pointed most strongly to the need for a profound change. The founder believes that shareholders will not trust any CEO proposed by the current board, so he has initiated the dispute for control of the board.

On the other hand, the Elliott Investment Management fund has accumulated a stake of more than one billion dollars in Lululemon and has announced its bet on Jane Nielsen, former Ralph Lauren executive, as the next CEO.

Wilson accumulates a 9% stake in Lululemon

Wilson stepped down as CEO of Lululemon in 2005, with the sale of 48% of the company to private equity firm Advent International. The company went public in 2007, with a valuation in excess of $1.2 billion.

The founder held the chairmanship until 2013, when a scandal over a television interview caused him to resign. He left the board for good in 2015 and, since then, up to four CEOs have tried to bring stability to the company.

Wilson later invested in Amer Sports, the Finnish sportswear parent company of outdoor brands such as Arc’teryx, Wilson, Salomon and Atomic; as well as in China’s Anta, one of the world’s largest sports industry groups, which is reportedly considering buying Puma.

The latest results recently published point to a two-speed fiscal year for Lululemon. The company posted a turnover of $2,565.9 million in the third quarter of the year, up 7% from the same period last year. However, its net profit fell by 12.8%, from $351.9 million in the third quarter of 2024 to $306.8 million in the same period of the current fiscal year.

name: Walmart
title: Daryk Pengelly, Former Head of Membership & Business Development at Walmart Business ...
description:
BOSTON--(BUSINESS WIRE)--Teikametrics, the leading AI-powered optimization platform, today announced that Daryk Pengelly has joined as Senior Vice President of Strategy and Business Development, where he will lead strategy and strategic partnerships to drive growth and expand the platform’s impact on eCommerce brands.
He joins Teikametrics from Walmart Business, where he was a co-founding leader and Head of Membership & Business Development.
Earlier in his career, Pengelly served as Senior Manager in Walmart’s Corporate Strategy group that worked on behalf of the Walmart C-Suite and Board of Directors.
He also served as Chief of Staff of Walmart’s Digital Brands group, which launched new brands such as Allswell and Free Assembly.
“I’m energized by Teikametrics’ mission, the team, and the opportunity to drive meaningful results for our customers and partners,” said Pengelly.
text:
di

Business Wire

-

The veteran consumer and B2B growth executive brings more than two decades of cross‑industry leadership and go‑to‑market experience to accelerate strategic growth and partnerships at Teikametrics.

BOSTON--(BUSINESS WIRE)--Teikametrics, the leading AI-powered optimization platform, today announced that Daryk Pengelly has joined as Senior Vice President of Strategy and Business Development, where he will lead strategy and strategic partnerships to drive growth and expand the platform’s impact on eCommerce brands.

"Daryk’s wealth of experience in scaling high-growth businesses, coupled with his deep understanding of the B2B and consumer markets, makes him the ideal leader to help us accelerate key areas of the business as we continue to expand the reach and impact of our platform," said Alasdair McLean-Foreman, CEO of Teikametrics.

Pengelly brings over two decades of leadership experience across both private startups and global Fortune 500 companies. He joins Teikametrics from Walmart Business, where he was a co-founding leader and Head of Membership & Business Development. During his tenure, his leadership in go-to-market initiatives helped accelerate brand awareness, membership expansion, and incremental GMV for Walmart Business. Pengelly also played a key role in launching Walmart's first B2B eCommerce membership program, negotiating marketing partnerships, and driving exponential membership growth.

Before Walmart, Pengelly served as a senior leader at Virgin Pulse, where he helped scale the B2B SaaS health and wellness platform that was acquired by Marlin and later merged with HealthComp to form Personify Health. He also spent several years at Reebok, leading brand strategy and special projects for the Reebok Classic lifestyle business, where he managed global influencer and celebrity marketing initiatives.

Earlier in his career, Pengelly served as Senior Manager in Walmart’s Corporate Strategy group that worked on behalf of the Walmart C-Suite and Board of Directors. He also served as Chief of Staff of Walmart’s Digital Brands group, which launched new brands such as Allswell and Free Assembly. He has also provided independent advisory services and has served on the Board of Advisors for the Overtown Youth Center in Miami, Florida.

“I’m energized by Teikametrics’ mission, the team, and the opportunity to drive meaningful results for our customers and partners,” said Pengelly.

Pengelly holds an AB, cum laude, from Harvard College and an MBA from MIT Sloan School of Management, where he was awarded a Dean’s Fellowship.

For more information, please visit: http://www.teikametrics.com

About Teikametrics

Teikametrics' AI-powered Marketplace Optimization Platform helps sellers and brand owners maximize their potential on the world's most valuable marketplaces. Founded in 2015, Teikametrics uses proprietary AI technology to maximize profitability in a simple SaaS interface. Teikametrics optimizes more than $10 billion in GMV across thousands of sellers around the world, with brands including Munchkin, Clarks, Nutribullet, Conair, Nutrafol, and Solo Stove trusting Teikametrics to unlock the full potential of their selling and advertising on Amazon, Walmart, and other marketplaces.

Contacts

Melissa Romig

Teikametrics

mromig@teikametrics.com

text:
What is a cookie?

A cookie is a small data file stored in your computer, tablet or smartphone. A cookie is not a program that can contain harmful malware or virus.

How our website uses cookies

Some cookies perform essential functions for our website. Cookies also help us get an overview of your visit to our website so we can continuously optimize and tailor the experience to your needs and interests. For example, cookies remember things like the items added to the shopping cart; whether you have visited our website before; if you are logged in; and the specific language and currency you prefer to see on the website. We also use cookies to target our ads specifically to you on other websites. In general, we use cookies as part of our service to present you with content that is as relevant to you as possible.

You can see the specific services that store cookies and why they do it, under the different categories:

Functional

How long are cookies stored?

The length of time a cookie is stored on your devices and browsers varies. The lifetime is calculated according to your last visit to the website. When a cookie expires, it is automatically deleted. All our cookies’ lifetimes are specified in our cookie policy.

How to block or delete cookies

You may at any time block all or just third-party cookies completely by changing the browser settings on your computer, tablet or smartphone. The location of these settings will depend on the browser you use. However, you should be aware that if you block all or just third-party cookies, there may be functions and services that you will be unable to use on the website (because these depend on cookies).

You can opt-out of cookies from Google Analytics here.

How can you delete cookies?

It is easy to delete cookies that you have previously accepted. It depends on which browser (Chrome, Firefox, Safari, etc.) and device (smartphone, tablet, PC, Mac) you are using.

You can typically find this information under settings – Security and Privacy – but this may vary from one browser to another. Specify which device/browser you are using (click the appropriate link):

text:
TreeHouse Foods (NYSE:THS)

Whether it be packaged crackers, broths, or beverages, Treehouse Foods (NYSE:THS) produces a wide range of private-label foods for grocery and food service customers.

TreeHouse Foods reported revenues of $841.9 million, down 1.5% year on year, falling short of analysts’ expectations by 1%. It was a disappointing quarter as it posted a significant miss of analysts’ EBITDA and gross margin estimates.

Interestingly, the stock is up 24.3% since the results and currently trades at $23.68.

Read our full analysis of TreeHouse Foods’s results here.

Hormel Foods (NYSE:HRL)

Best known for its SPAM brand, Hormel (NYSE:HRL) is a packaged foods company with products that span meat, poultry, shelf-stable foods, and spreads.

Hormel Foods reported revenues of $3.19 billion, up 1.5% year on year. This result came in 2% below analysts' expectations. Aside from that, it was a satisfactory quarter as it also recorded a solid beat of analysts’ EBITDA estimates but a miss of analysts’ revenue estimates.

Hormel Foods had the weakest performance against analyst estimates among its peers. The stock is up 3% since reporting and currently trades at $24.12.

Read our full, actionable report on Hormel Foods here, it’s free for active Edge members.

Kraft Heinz (NASDAQ:KHC)

The result of a 2015 mega-merger between Kraft and Heinz, Kraft Heinz (NASDAQ:KHC) is a packaged foods giant whose products span coffee to cheese to packaged meat.

Kraft Heinz reported revenues of $6.24 billion, down 2.3% year on year. This print was in line with analysts’ expectations. Taking a step back, it was a slower quarter as it logged a significant miss of analysts’ organic revenue estimates and a miss of analysts’ gross margin estimates.

The stock is down 5.3% since reporting and currently trades at $24.09.

Read our full, actionable report on Kraft Heinz here, it’s free for active Edge members.

Market Update

In response to the Fed’s rate hikes in 2022 and 2023, inflation has been gradually trending down from its post-pandemic peak, trending closer to the Fed’s 2% target. Despite higher borrowing costs, the economy has avoided flashing recessionary signals. This is the much-desired soft landing that many investors hoped for. The recent rate cuts (0.5% in September and 0.25% in November 2024) have bolstered the stock market, making 2024 a strong year for equities. Donald Trump’s presidential win in November sparked additional market gains, sending indices to record highs in the days following his victory. However, debates continue over possible tariffs and corporate tax adjustments, raising questions about economic stability in 2025.

description:
Sandwiched between the holiday shopping wrap-up and the year-end markdown season, the Bank of New York Mellon Corp. announced a different sort of celebratory gift.
BNY said it is marking the United States’ 250th birthday in 2026 with a new initiative that celebrates the nation’s financial foundations, BNY’s contributions and how the country’s innovation is helping to power the future of finance and economies everywhere.
The oldest bank in the U.S., BNY was founded in 1784 and has played a unique role in the development of America’s financial markets and economy.
In 2026, the company will spotlight key market advancements such as faster payments, AI and digital infrastructure that will help shape future economic growth.

name: Kraft Heinz
title: Packaging industry continues to seek sustainability | Supermarket Perimeter
description:
Despite decades of a push toward more sustainable packaging, the consumer goods industry has yet to find a truly circular solution.
The direction of packaging trends has morphed over the past decades, especially as society has wrestled with finding a balance between food preservation and sustainability.
“I’ve heard packaging described as a superhero — that we’re just asking it to do so many things,” said Allison Reser, director of sustainability and innovation at the Pet Sustainability Coalition.
“In the regenerative robust gasification process, we can handle all of these materials,” Welt said.
“It’s not up to a meat and poultry manufacturer to not provide packaging because someone might litter with it.
text:
One thing packaging professionals can agree upon is we’re not where we need to be. Despite decades of a push toward more sustainable packaging, the consumer goods industry has yet to find a truly circular solution.

So often in packaging innovation, durability competes with sustainability. At a time when consumer confidence in food safety is on the decline, retaining strong barriers in meat and poultry packaging remains critical. Yet, sacrificing environmentally friendly materials and processes is not an option either.

The direction of packaging trends has morphed over the past decades, especially as society has wrestled with finding a balance between food preservation and sustainability.

“There was a shift as I started my career to removing the butcher from the supermarket,” said Bruce Welt, PhD, professor of packaging engineering at the University of Florida. “There was that period initially where there was a guy in a bloody smock with knives that was cutting up meat. He or she would wrap it in a Styrofoam-type tray and slap a label on it. That was unbranded and store packaged.

“Then with the advent of modified atmosphere packaging (MAP) and to some extent some use of carbon monoxide … a variety of packages came out.”

Innovations like the vacuum skin pack, master packs and semi-rigid trays were introduced.

“The vacuum skin packs brought multi-layer barrier film with fantastic graphics,” Welt said. “The MAP trays brought a sense of cleanliness. They weren’t leaking. And also a variety of films that either were highly permeable or not permeable, and then the whole variety of foodservice packaging — chubs and everything else — a great variety of materials that achieved the purpose and served humanity in a very efficient way. These are very low-cost, high-performing applications that now people are not happy with for some reason.”

The dissatisfaction Welt referred to is often due to the difficulty of recycling materials used in these multi-layer materials.

“I’ve heard packaging described as a superhero — that we’re just asking it to do so many things,” said Allison Reser, director of sustainability and innovation at the Pet Sustainability Coalition.

Reser noted that multi-material films feature several layers to serve a distinct purpose, whether that’s strength, moisture, oxygen, etc.

“There’s a lot of thought that’s been put into that design, but that design inherently is very difficult to recycle or do something with after it’s done because, to recycle something, you technically need to peel apart all those different layers and then turn those back into resins to then turn back into something else,” she explained.

What’s in the bag actually matters a lot more than the bag itself, according to Reser, as packaging typically only makes up 10% to 30% of a product’s overall environmental impact.

“But at the same time, I think we can do better,” Reser said. “We can streamline the functions of the package to design in true circularity.”

A proposed solution

For Reser, improvement looks like considering both the short-term and the long-term.

On the short-term, Reser encourages companies to switch to eco-friendly technology like mono-material packaging that is already available at scale.

“But then, even mono-material plastic or paper, those aren’t regenerative solutions,” Reser said. “They are less bad than other options. But long term I would love to see more innovation and focus on truly circular solutions.”

Welt has been working on developing exactly that — a circular solution for the packaging waste problem.

His team of researchers at the University of Florida have created what’s known as Regenerative Robust Gasification (RRG), an advanced recycling system that is able to take in any form of packaging material, and without the need to sort or separate, it can convert those substances into synthesis gas. From synthesis gas, many practical applications can be formed, but Welt advocates for the usage of methanol in particular.

“It’s a very versatile compound, synthesis gas; however, it’s not easy to transport,” Welt said. “In order to make this widely available to manufacturing, we have to convert it into something that can be transported. And the simplest thing to do is methanol.”

Welt noted that a lot of packaging today is not recyclable in our existing system — anything with mixed materials, including labels.

“In the regenerative robust gasification process, we can handle all of these materials,” Welt said. “With the right infrastructure for handling our waste, we don’t have to think as much about the materials. We can think more about the packaging application.”

Reser agrees that a new chemical recycling system could have a positive impact on redirecting material waste.

“My take on any of these advanced recycling systems is that it seems like a promising short-term solution to deal with all of this material that we already have out in the world,” she said.

However, Reser expressed caution in saying the technology could solve all the industry’s problems, given other factors that need to be taken into consideration.

“Is it using a lot more energy? Is it using a lot more water? Are there trade-offs that we need to consider before we go all into that kind of technology?” she asked.

Government involvement

As researchers and innovators continue to look for ways to improve the current recycling system, legislation has played more of a role in recent years in an attempt to address the issue.

To date, seven states — Maine, Oregon, Colorado, California, Minnesota, Maryland and Washington — have introduced Extended Producer Responsibility (EPR) legislation. The laws require food manufacturers to pay fees to manage the recycling of their products rather than holding municipalities and taxpayers financially and operationally responsible.

“That incentivizing companies to switch to better packaging is one positive outcome of these laws,” Reser said. “The other intent is that, with those fees, the municipalities are able to improve their recycling infrastructure.”

While Reser sees the implementation of EPRs as a step in the right direction toward creating a more sustainable future, Welt finds concerns with the new laws.

“I think ultimately the responsibility is on the municipality; it’s not on the producer,” he said.

“It’s the responsibility of the municipality through law enforcement to punish litterers,” Welt elaborated. “It’s not up to a meat and poultry manufacturer to not provide packaging because someone might litter with it. That’s just insane.”

Welt explained his viewpoint that the EPR laws are a violation of the Commerce Clause.

“When the Articles of Confederation were done in the United States, and we were a bunch of different states with their independent power before the Constitution, that’s what they were doing to each other — the states were taxing each other,” he said. “When we had the Constitution, the founders saw that this was a significant problem impeding interstate commerce, so they specifically put into the Constitution that states wouldn’t tariff other states, and that’s effectively what EPR is.”

Welt noted that EPR is currently being challenged in Oregon.

“Hopefully EPR will be a flash in the pan, and we will figure out a way to get away from that,” he said. “But I would certainly say that the industry should stop just bending over and taking this stuff and really put up a fight and not acquiesce to EPR.”

name: Philips
title: Samsung TVs about to get a big Google upgrade – but not quite how you'd expect | T3
description:
Samsung is turning to Google for the next feature coming to its televisions, but it's not going to be the adoption of Google TV over the company's Tizen interface.
Instead, Samsung plans to bring Google Photos to its televisions.
The addition of Google Photos will allow users to view images from their Google account, with Samsung detailing that deep integration is planned.
That will include Memories, Create with AI and Personalised Results, with Memories being an exclusive feature for Samsung TVs for the first 6 months.
Showing holiday snaps will be easy, while it looks like Samsung will also bubble up memories similar to Google Photos based around time.
text:
Samsung is turning to Google for the next feature coming to its televisions, but it's not going to be the adoption of Google TV over the company's Tizen interface. Instead, Samsung plans to bring Google Photos to its televisions.

The addition of Google Photos will allow users to view images from their Google account, with Samsung detailing that deep integration is planned. That will see Google Photos accessed as part of Daily+ and Daily Board for a seamless experience, while there are plans to have a number of ways to curate the images seen.

That will include Memories, Create with AI and Personalised Results, with Memories being an exclusive feature for Samsung TVs for the first 6 months. This exclusivity is familiar territory for Samsung and an key indicator that these features will be available on other platforms too – most likely Google TV which is found on Sony, Philips and other TVs.

Memories will allow you to curate stories based on people or locations to be shown on your Samsung TV. That sounds like a great way to show off the grandkids at a family gathering, for example.

Create with AI uses templates built on Nano Banana to transform photos into something more interesting, while Personalised Results will show photos related to topics, like a place or activity.

That means it's not just going to be a random selection of Google Photos that get displayed, but something that you have more control over.

An indication of future TV features?

The move suggests that Google is looking for ways to unlock some of its content and make it available elsewhere. Photos aren't new on TVs: most platforms already offer some way to show images, whether through access to a particular online gallery or via casting in some form.

But these always seem a little random where you never know what's going to be shown. Moving toward a personally curated experience will provide the satisfaction that users want, knowing that it's not just going to be a collection of screenshots, photos of the floor and all the rest of the stuff that fills your Google Photos library.

Instead, I'm expecting to be able to call up pictures of the cat to share with everyone all the time. Showing holiday snaps will be easy, while it looks like Samsung will also bubble up memories similar to Google Photos based around time.

Samsung says that these features will appear through 2026, with Memories the first to arrive in early 2026, followed by the other two options "later in 2026".

name: Kraft Heinz
title: Hormel names new chief marketing officer - Supermarket Perimeter
description:
AUSTIN, MINN. — Hormel Foods Corp., recently announced Jason Levine was appointed to the newly created role of enterprise-wide chief marketing officer (CMO).
Most recently, Levine served as CMO for PIM Brands, a snacking confectionery company producing products that include Welch’s fruit snacks.
At Hormel, Levine will focus on advancing marketing capabilities across the company and enabling enterprise-wide growth.
Levine will focus on brand strategy, digital capabilities, and the creation of marketing platforms that scale across channels and markets.
Levin’s previous job experience includes marketing leadership roles at Kraft Foods Group, where he contributed to brand development and portfolio growth initiatives.
text:
AUSTIN, MINN. — Hormel Foods Corp., recently announced Jason Levine was appointed to the newly created role of enterprise-wide chief marketing officer (CMO).

Levine has more than 20 years of experience in consumer-packaged goods for global brands and emerging companies.

“We’re excited to have Jason join us and take on this new role — an important step in advancing our marketing capabilities and driving growth across all segments of our business,” said John Ghingo, president of Hormel Foods. “Jason brings deep expertise in global brand building, innovation and digital strategy across well-known brands, and his leadership will help us unlock the full potential of our iconic brands and accelerate our long-range growth ambitions.”

Levine worked 19 years with Mondelēz International, beginning at Kraft Foods Group. He eventually moved into a role of Mondelēz’s CMO for North America, where he led marketing for a multibillion-dollar portfolio of brands, including OREO and RITZ, driving innovation, brand modernization, and cross-category growth in highly competitive markets.

Most recently, Levine served as CMO for PIM Brands, a snacking confectionery company producing products that include Welch’s fruit snacks.

At Hormel, Levine will focus on advancing marketing capabilities across the company and enabling enterprise-wide growth. Levine will focus on brand strategy, digital capabilities, and the creation of marketing platforms that scale across channels and markets.

Other aspects include enterprise business analytics which will now be aligned with the company’s Brand Fuel function, its hub for innovation, consumer and shopper insights, brand diagnostics, e‑commerce, digital content and brand communications.

Levin’s previous job experience includes marketing leadership roles at Kraft Foods Group, where he contributed to brand development and portfolio growth initiatives. Most recently, Levine held senior roles at PIM Brands, Whisps Snacks and Sabra Dipping Co., where he led category expansion, introduced new product lines and advanced digital engagement strategies.

Levine earned his MBA from Tulane University and a bachelor’s degree in business from Northeastern University.

name: Ralph Lauren
title: Chip Wilson pushing for leadership change on Lululemon board - Powell River Peak
description:
VANCOUVER — Chip Wilson says he has nominated three director candidates for Lululemon Athletica Inc.'s board as he seeks changes in leadership and strategy at the company he founded.
Wilson says in a statement that the current board lacks the "visionary creative leadership" needed for the company to thrive.
His three candidates include Marc Maurer, former co-chief executive of On Holding AG, Laura Gentile, former chief marketing officer of ESPN and Eric Hirshberg, former chief executive officer of Activision.
Wilson, who remains a large shareholder in the company, has said the CEO search should be led by new, independent directors.
Meanwhile, activist investor Elliott Management has built a stake of more than US$1 billion in Lululemon and is pushing for the struggling retailer to name former Ralph Lauren executive Jane Nielsen as its next chief executive.
text:
VANCOUVER — Chip Wilson says he has nominated three director candidates for Lululemon Athletica Inc.'s board as he seeks changes in leadership and strategy at the company he founded.

Wilson says in a statement that the current board lacks the "visionary creative leadership" needed for the company to thrive.

His three candidates include Marc Maurer, former co-chief executive of On Holding AG, Laura Gentile, former chief marketing officer of ESPN and Eric Hirshberg, former chief executive officer of Activision.

The nominations come after the company announced earlier this month that current CEO Calvin McDonald would step down from his role effective Jan. 31, with the search for a new leader underway.

Wilson, who remains a large shareholder in the company, has said the CEO search should be led by new, independent directors.

Meanwhile, activist investor Elliott Management has built a stake of more than US$1 billion in Lululemon and is pushing for the struggling retailer to name former Ralph Lauren executive Jane Nielsen as its next chief executive.

This report by The Canadian Press was first published Dec. 29, 2025.

The Canadian Press

title: How a dinner chat led to a vaginal care startup that won over Walmart, Target

name: Nvidia
title: Nvidia gives Intel a lifeline with $5 billion common stock deal - Tom's Hardware
description:
Back in September, Nvidia announced a historic equity investment into Intel worth $5 billion, joining the U.S. government in lending a lifeline to the floundering American chipmaker.
Today, Intel has officially sold 214.7 million shares to Nvidia at $23.28 per share, reports Reuters.
Over the years, Intel's massive capex spending had put a strain on its financials, which was paired with growing national security concerns over CEO Lip-Bu Tan's former ties to China.
Shortly after these two announcements, Intel and Nvidia unveiled the Intel x86 RTX SoCs, but these weren't a product of the Trump administration's involvement.
Rather, this unlikely partnership had been in the works for some time, and was allegedly already in the works before any U.S. investment was made.
text:
Back in September, Nvidia announced a historic equity investment into Intel worth $5 billion, joining the U.S. government in lending a lifeline to the floundering American chipmaker. Today, Intel has officially sold 214.7 million shares to Nvidia at $23.28 per share, reports Reuters. At the time of the original announcement, that number was 6% above market price, but it's now 36% below what Intel is currently trading at.

The purchase was cleared by the FTC in early December, so it was only a matter of time before we received this news. Intel is worth $172.67 billion at the time of writing, a drastic recovery from 2024 and much of 2025, where it had been valued as low as $82.71 billion.

Over the years, Intel's massive capex spending had put a strain on its financials, which was paired with growing national security concerns over CEO Lip-Bu Tan's former ties to China. Just a few months ago, this commotion had transpired into a dire situation where President Trump was seeking to oust CEO Lip-Bu Tan, but the two eventually reconciled, leading to Washington purchasing an $8.9 billion stake in Intel.

Shortly after these two announcements, Intel and Nvidia unveiled the Intel x86 RTX SoCs, but these weren't a product of the Trump administration's involvement. Rather, this unlikely partnership had been in the works for some time, and was allegedly already in the works before any U.S. investment was made.

There's no release window for the upcoming RTX SoCs, and it'll take some time before any fruit is borne from the new partnership. But, it's safe to say they whenever they land, it could mark a significant shift in the industry, especially with a revitalized Intel at the helm. The chipmaker's foundry business has also started to find new life, with potential to challenge TSMC's U.S operations, thanks to its early adoption of High-NA EUV lithography.

text:
NVIDIA Corporation stocks trading down by -1.99% as market anticipates fresh innovations amid ongoing AI trends.

Live Update At 10:03:00 EST: On Monday, December 29, 2025 NVIDIA Corporation stock [NASDAQ: NVDA] is trending down by -1.99%! Discover the key drivers behind this movement as well as our expert analysis in the detailed breakdown below.

Earnings Report and Financial Overview

One of the key strategies for traders is to remain objective and not let emotions drive trading decisions. As Tim Bohen, lead trainer with StocksToTrade, says, “I focus on what a stock is doing, not what I want it to do. Let the stock prove itself before you make a move.” This approach emphasizes the importance of analyzing actual market performance instead of being swayed by personal desires or expectations. By adhering to this mindset, traders can make more informed and strategic decisions, rather than relying on assumptions or wishful thinking.

Nvidia recently released its earnings report reflecting a landscape filled with strong profits alongside growing challenges. The company reported a massive revenue jump, showcasing $130.5B, aligning with unstoppable demand in GPU markets. With an enterprise valuation reaching close to $4.8T, Nvidia’s financial health seems robust from a snapshot view. However, peeling back the layers reveals complexities.

For starters, Nvidia’s remarkable 62.2% EBIT margin indicates operational efficiency. Yet the high P/E ratio standing at 47.28 raises eyebrows among cautious investors. From an income statement perspective, their EBITDA reported at $38.72B signifies substantial earnings before accounting adjustments.

In the broader context, Nvidia’s adaptive strategies reflect in its decision to forego Intel’s process in its chip production lines. This move didn’t fly well with investors, judging by the negative ripples in stock valuations. Moreover, strategic moves like SoftBank’s unloading of Nvidia shares indeed inject a layer of uncertainty, although Nvidia basks in investor goodwill built from years of innovation.

The shadows of Google’s aggressive push into AI computing loom, potentially slicing into Nvidia’s market share in the coming quarters. And Nvidia’s restructuring within the cloud division underscores a pivot from previously competitive stances to perhaps a collaborative or niche-focused approach. This news of high-ranking executives stepping aside introduces subtle doubts about the future trajectory of Nvidia’s cloud dominance.

Impact of Recent News on Stock

SoftBank Divestment: A Bold Move?

SoftBank is no stranger to bold moves, and its latest decision to partially divest from Nvidia is just that. Aimed at bolstering its commitment to OpenAI, this maneuver saw SoftBank selling hefty stakes. The shift, while financially driven for SoftBank, casts a slight cloud over Nvidia, indicating a multifaceted relationship entwined with market strategizing and fulfilling fiscal promises.

For Nvidia, it beckons investors to re-evaluate strategic ties and dependencies. Indeed, every shift prompts a corresponding adjustment in share price, especially when magnitude and timing mix into the equation.

Competitive Edge at Stake: Google’s Innovation

Google, with its fingers in the pie of AI computing, poses more than a mild threat to Nvidia’s stronghold. Google’s new initiative isn’t just a sideline attraction; it’s an audacious leap into territories Nvidia inhabits confidently. While Nvidia’s core audience expects innovation, the duel for dominance in AI computing could alter financial landscapes moving forward.

Should Google succeed in capturing even a fraction of Nvidia’s target audience, the implications on profits and market stance would be tangible. Nvidia’s investors are right to pay close attention—these developments could very well dictate stock performance over lengthy periods.

Leadership Changes: Strategic Restructuring

Nvidia’s internal shake-up in the cloud sector may seem minor, but in strategic landscapes, they can signify deeper objectives. By restructuring the cloud division and shifting talented executives, Nvidia hints at realigning operational trajectories. These shifts are likely intended to hedge against heavily resourced, competitor-dominated fields like those controlled by Amazon Web Services.

Such restructuring rarely leaves stock prices untouched. Investors mull over these decisions, contemplating long-term benefits against short-term disruptions. While beneficial restructuring is geared at maintaining innovative agility, its impartial results remain subject to speculation.

Future Directions and Considerations

In the wake of these pivotal shifts, Nvidia is embroiled in transformations likely to excite and challenge stakeholders alike. Its operational excellence discussed might sway market sentiments to positive or negative poles, depending significantly on upcoming executions of strategic pivots, especially in the cloud division.

Balancing profitability amidst fierce competition, both internal and strategic, will spotlight Nvidia’s nimble adaptability. In future quarters, Nvidia’s enduring superior performance will either shine a light on successful strategy or prompt reconsideration in the eyes of cautious market participants. As Tim Bohen, lead trainer with StocksToTrade says, “I never chase price. The best opportunities allow me to enter on my terms, not when I’m feeling pressured.” This philosophy might resonate with market traders observing Nvidia’s next moves, pushing them to assess entry points based on strategic successes rather than market hype.

Strategically, Nvidia needs to ensure its future-proofing measures, reinforcing areas like AI computing while bolstering its unique values against up-and-coming disruptors like Google’s. Dynamic industry movements necessitate equally adept responses, simultaneously assuring stakeholders while leveraging innovation to remain at industry pinnacles.

Navigating these competitive waters, Nvidia remains a stalwart, inspiring intrigue and analytical scrutiny worldwide. As the narrative develops, watch closely—Nvidia’s next moves are not just speculative intrigue, but essential business evolution recognized across technological and financial realms.

text:
Agentic Shopping Experiences

Price.com's Buy with AI Helps Shoppers Get Deals, Cashback & More

Price.com's Buy with AI is an agentic shopping experience that goes beyond supplying recommendations, enabling shoppers to find deals, get cashback and conveniently make purchases. Categories such as apparel, electronics, and home goods have historically experienced a drop-off at checkout, and this new experience leverages AI-led purchasing to reduce friction and disruption at the point of checkout.

"Nearly half of consumers are already using AI to help them shop, but most of those experiences still stop short," said RJ Jain, founder and CEO of Price.com. "They help you discover products, then leave you to figure out savings and checkout on your own. Price.com is built for what comes next, turning AI-driven intent into completed purchases, with savings, all in one place. Nearly a quarter of all purchases by Black Friday 2026 will be driven by Agentic AI experiences."

Trend Themes

1. AI-led Frictionless Commerce - AI-led purchasing systems are revolutionizing e-commerce by minimizing friction at the checkout stage, transforming customer experience.

2. Integrated AI-driven Savings - The integration of AI within shopping experiences facilitates seamless discovery and application of savings during the checkout process.

3. Agentic Shopping Transformation - Agentic AI is reshaping consumer shopping habits by turning AI-driven intent into completed transactions with added benefits like cashback.

Industry Implications

1. E-commerce Solutions - The rise of AI technologies in e-commerce is enabling more efficient and personalized shopping experiences for consumers.

2. Retail Technology Platforms - Retailers are adopting innovative technology platforms to enhance customer engagement and streamline the purchasing process.

3. Consumer Fintech Innovations - Financial tech innovations are growing within shopping platforms, offering more savings opportunities and cashback for consumers.

What I Liked From Hanover, Chris Black’s New Basics Brand
text:
Photo: Michael Zhao

Shopping at Hanover, longtime Strategist columnist Chris Black’s new clothing line, is like stumbling across a stash of perfectly faded vintage Ralph Lauren with none of the off-putting odors and stains associated with thrifted men’s sportswear. While not quite as cheap as vintage, the prices are surprisingly low for new clothes that are entirely produced in Los Angeles. The most expensive offering is a $155 pair of jeans made of deadstock North Carolinian denim — more than $100 cheaper than a comparable pair from Buck Mason.

It sounds too good to be true, but each piece I tried felt sturdily made from high-quality materials. I am a slender six-foot-two, which makes me a medium in most brands. But Hanover’s team sent large tops across the board, and that was definitely the right call. The first run is selling out quickly, so I wasn’t able to try everything, but I’ve compiled photos and notes for all the pieces I managed to test, starting with my favorites and ending with the rest.

Saved

View

Yes

New! You can now save this product for later.

This 100 percent cotton pique polo shirt made me nostalgic for the Ralph Lauren shirts I’d find in my dad’s closet as a kid: softened from decades of washing and drying with the reassuring heft of a garment that’s made to a higher standard than it needs to be. True to its description, it looks good tucked or untucked. And I especially appreciated how the collar still rests flatly against my upper chest when one or both buttons are unfastened, as I’m wont to wear it. At just under $100, it’s priced in line with what Todd Snyder charges for a similar unfaded style that’s produced in Portugal.

$125

Between its natural-looking fade, smallish hood, and metal grommets for a missing drawstring, this sweatshirt feels like something that could have been salvaged from a schoolyard lost and found in a good way. (Also available as a crewneck.) It’s much softer than the similarly priced and factory-faded Trash Hoodie from Everybody.World, and I’ve been enjoying throwing it over my PJs first thing in the morning when I roll out of bed to make my coffee. Although it’s said to be made from a 20-ounce fabric, it’s about 200 grams lighter than the 13-ounce Trash Hoodie, so I’d guess it’s closer to a 12-ounce.

Black is known to prefer vintage tees to new ones, so it’s no surprise that his idealized version of a new T-shirt would come prewashed to a perfectly worn-in fade and texture. I wear a 38R jacket and found the large fit perfectly. The shoulder seams fell right at the outer edge of my shoulders and the hem right above my crotch — short enough to look neat untucked yet long enough to tuck if a look calls for it. Besides this charcoal fade, it comes in red, green, and blue. Blink and you’ll miss the tonal-matched embroidered H logo on the bottom left.

Hanover Tote

$45

$45

It’s not that this isn’t a great tote; I just have to wonder whether everyone who snatched it up realized how big it was when they ordered it. At 15-by-18-by-5 inches, it’s about the same size as a large L.L.Bean Boat and Tote and can hold about a week’s worth of laundry — way too big for any kind of daily use. (It offers a mini-tote too, but no measurements are provided.) The canvas material is much less stiff than L.L.Bean’s, which makes it a bit more comfortable to carry. It also features a prominent American flag patch, which aligns with Hanover’s made-in-USA ethos but may give pause to some.

We are in the midst of a full-on denim-head revival, rivaling that of the Obama presidency, which is why I was excited to try these jeans made from deadstock Cone Mills denim, which ceased production in 2017. I got the lightwash fade in a size 30 and was impressed by their construction and material quality. The fade looks natural and credibly vintage — the subtly abraded hems and edges really sell it, and the suede brand patch with the belt pass-through has a luxuriously soft texture that should develop a nice patina over time. But the cut through the thighs was so slim that I could feel it constricting my circulation every time I sat down. Based on how these pants fit the models in the product photos, sizing up to a 32 would have likely helped achieve the more tapered fit I look for in a pair of jeans (see the made-in-USA vintage Levi’s 550s for reference), but that would definitely require a belt, since the 30 fit me well in the waist.

Adobe Inc. (NASDAQ:ADBE) is among the most undervalued tech giants to buy according to hedge funds. As of December 26, Adobe Inc. (NASDAQ:ADBE) has a ‘Buy’ or equivalent rating from 67% of the analysts covering the stock. With a median price target of $422.50, the stock has an upside potential of 19.73%. On December 17, Tyler Radke from Citi raised the price target on ADBE to $387 from $366 and kept a ‘Neutral’ rating. This revision, implying an upside potential of approximately 10%, follows the company’s updated model following the fiscal Q4 report. According to the analyst, the quarter demonstrated upside, but the fiscal 2026 outlook was mixed.

When Adobe Inc. (NASDAQ:ADBE) announced its fourth-quarter results on December 10, the company outperformed with an EPS estimate of $5.50, marginally above projections of $5.40. Similarly, the company delivered a revenue of $6.19 billion, surpassing the forecasted $6.11 billion. Since then, several analysts have adjusted their forecasts.

Rawpixel.com/Shutterstock.com

On December 15, BMO Capital trimmed the price target on Adobe Inc. (NASDAQ:ADBE) to $400 from $405, keeping an ‘Outperform’ rating. Earlier on December 11, Evercore ISI reduced the price target to $425 from $450 and reiterated an ‘Outperform’ rating. The firm noted that although the company’s FY26 guidance is solid, the outlook reflects moderate growth relative to FY25.

Adobe Inc. (NASDAQ:ADBE) is a California-based technology company operating through Digital Media, Document Cloud, Creative Cloud, Digital Experience, and Publishing and Advertising segments. Founded in 1982, the company is committed to changing “the world through personalized digital experiences.”

While we acknowledge the potential of ADBE as an investment, we believe certain AI stocks offer greater upside potential and carry less downside risk. (NASDAQ:CSCO) has a ‘Buy’ or equivalent rating from slightly more than half of the analysts covering the stock. Among the analysts with a neutral view on the stock is Tim Long, an analyst at Barclays, who reaffirmed a ‘Hold’ rating on CSCO and set a price target of $76 on December 11.

Later on December 17, Morgan Stanley lifted the price target on Cisco Systems, Inc. (NASDAQ:CSCO) to $91 from $82, and kept the ‘Overweight’ rating unchanged. Yuganov Konstantin/Shutterstock.com

Trade can continue its momentum, particularly in optical, through the first half of next year, but investors will “need to get more selective for full year returns given multiples,” the analyst added in a year-ahead note on the group.

On the same day, Cisco Systems, Inc. (NASDAQ:CSCO) announced that shareholders approved an amended and restated version of the company’s 2005 Stock Incentive Plan at its annual meeting held a day earlier. Under the revised plan, the number of shares authorized will increase by 57,490,000 shares.
